Sarah Jones Loyd }} '''Samuel Jones-Loyd, 1st Baron Overstone''' (25 September 1796 – 17 November 1883) was a British banker and politician. ==Background and education== Loyd was the only son of Reverend Lewis Loyd and Sarah, daughter of John Jones, a [[Manchester]] banker.[http://www.thepeerage.com/p2171.htm#i21706 Samuel Jones Loyd, 1st and last Baron Overstone] He was educated at [[Eton College|Eton]] and [[Trinity College, Cambridge]].{{acad|id=LT813SJ|name = Loyd,Samuel Jones}} ==Banking== Loyd's father had given up the ministry to take a partnership in his father-in-law's bank and became the founder of the London branch of Jones, Loyd & Co. Loyd joined his father's bank, and took control of the bank after his father retired in 1844. On his father's death in 1858 Loyd inherited an estate worth [[Pound sterling|£]] 2 million. In 1864 the bank became incorporated with the [[London and Westminster Bank]].[http://www.rbs.com/about03.asp?id=ABOUT_US/OUR_HERITAGE/OUR_HISTORY/OUR_BANKING_FAMILY/PAST_CONSTITUENTS/LONDON_AND_WESTMINSTER_BANK RBS History] ==Political career== Loyd sat in parliament as [[Whig (British political faction)|Whig]] member for [[Hythe (UK Parliament constituency)|Hythe]] from 1819 to 1826,[http://www.leighrayment.com/commons/Hcommons4.htm leighrayment.com House of Commons: Horncastle to Hythe] and unsuccessfully contested [[Manchester (UK Parliament constituency)|Manchester]] in 1832. As early as 1832 he was recognized as one of the foremost authorities on banking, and he enjoyed much influence with successive ministries and [[Chancellor of the Exchequer|chancellors of the exchequer]]. Loyd is considered as one of the great figures in British monetary history, particularly with respect to the [[Bank Charter Act of 1844]]. He was also opposed to [[limited liability]] and the introduction of a [[decimal currency]]. In 1850 he was raised to the peerage as '''Baron Overstone''', of Overstone and of Fotheringhay, both in the County of Northampton.{{London Gazette|issue=21073 |date=1 March 1850 |startpage=653 }} Lord Overstone was a member of [[The Club (Literary Club)]] and the [[Political Economy Club]] and served as [[High Sheriff of Warwickshire]] in 1838{{London Gazette|issue=19586|startpage=232|date=2 February 1838}} and as [[President of the Royal Statistical Society]] from 1851 to 1853. In 1847 and 1848, he served on the committee of the British Relief Association, which raised almost half a million pounds on behalf of the famine victims in Ireland. (see,Christine Kinealy, Charity and the Great Hunger. The Kindness of Strangers'. Bloomsbury, 2013 Christine Kinealy, Charity and the Great Hunger. The Kindness of Strangers'. Bloomsbury, 2013) ==Family== Lord Overstone married Harriet, daughter of Ichabod Wright, in 1829. They had one son, who died as an infant, and a daughter. His seat was Wolvey Hall, [[Wolvey]], [[Warwickshire]], which he purchased in 1815.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} Lady Overstone died in November 1864. Overstone remained a widower until his death in November 1883, aged 87. The barony died with him as he had no surviving male issue. The majority of his considerable fortune was passed on to his daughter, the Honourable Harriet Sarah Loyd. She was the wife of [[Robert Loyd-Lindsay, 1st Baron Wantage|Robert Lindsay]], who assumed the additional surname of Loyd and was created Baron Wantage in 1885.
